Comto stock resources update. Each week we try to cover one to two companies we've discussed in previous podcast video cast for our own clients, including personally I eat my own cooking. In late 2023, we came out publicly with a new position in Comtock Resources, a name that had been left for dead and one you practically couldn't give away. A combination of record domestic natural gas production, flooding inventories, milder weather, lowering demand, and being blindsided by policies slowing LNG export projects crushed the stock and sent natural gas prices to their lowest inflation adjusted levels since they began trading on the NY in 1990. We saw this as an opportunity and started adding around $8 a share basis. Two things stood out to us that made Comtock a no-brainer. First, we were investing with Jerry Jones. Second, Comtock is the lowest cost producer with a cost structure that's 48% lower than pure averages. We believe in the long-term natural gas theme, and Comtock is undoubtedly the most efficiently run pure play in the space. Comtock was quietly playing offense looking for the next big drilling opportunity. management spent the last 5 years studying geologic data and signing over 20,000 new drilling leases across a massive 520,000 netacre footprint in the western Hannesville region. This region is still virtually undeveloped with management calling it the holy grail because they expect it to yield significantly more resource potential per section than their legacy Hannesville assets with potential for thousands of future drilling locations. Meanwhile, it's perfectly situated about 100 miles from both Houston and Dallas prime locations for future data centers that management is already in discussions for. With LG capacity growing and AI and data centers driving electricity demand to record levels, the real question over the next few years will be where will all the natural gas come from? Comtock will happily be there to answer just that. US electricity consumption from the EIA 1990 to 2026 is up close to 60%. US Henry Hub natural gas spot price going up. Global energy.
